lang.key: Maintained by Madison Kelly (mkelly@alteeve.ca) for the Striker.
If you aren't sure what to do, please contact support.

############################################################################## # Please do not put any variables other than 'Host' sections below here. # # At this time, only 'Host / Port' is supported. Please use ~/.ssh/config if # # you need to specify additional options for a given host. # ##############################################################################

# The file is maintained by #!string!brand_0002!#. If you modify this manually, entries will # be preserved but formatting and comments will not. ::1 localhost localhost.localdomain localhost6 localhost6.localdomain6

### #!string!brand_0001!# - Generated on: [#!variable!date_and_time!#] by: [#!variable!program!#]. # This is an auto-generated file. Manual change should be preserved when it is # updated but bugs may exist. Backups will be created with the date and time as # the file name suffix. If manually added values are lost, please contact # support: #!string!brand_0012!#
Add a new #!string!brand_0003!#, edit an existing one or delete a retired system.
The physical disks below are not currently a member of any logical disk.
Configure mail server(s) to use when sending alert emails.

This can be whatever you want, but it must be unique.
It is good to keep this short.

This fine-tunes the hypervisor for your operating system.
If your OS is not listed, choose the one that is the closest match.

This will open a new window where you can upload new disc images.
Once finished, please reload this page to see them.
You server will boot and install of this disc.

If you need a drivers to install your server,
please select the appropriate disc here.
Most servers work well between 2 and 8 GiB, with 64 MiB being the minimum.
Windows servers tend to work best with 2 CPUs.
More is not always better. When in doubt, start with 2 to 4. You can change this easily later.
Please use only one node's storage pool.

Enter a fixed size or a percentage of remaining free space to use for this server.
If you separate two sizes with a colon, like '80:250 [ GiB ]', it will create two partition
sized '80 GiB' for the first drive and '250 GiB' for the second one.
This is the user names used to log in to you IPMI interface.
If you need to use "Lanplus" to talk to the node's IPMI interface, change this to '#!string!state_0038!#'. This is often needed for HP Proliant nodes.
The "#!variable!field!#" must be a fully qualified domain name. If you do not want to use your domain name, use x.localdomain or similar.
Downloading a file from the internet can take a long time!
Please be sure that the web address above is a direct link to the file you want to download.
Some websites use referral links which may not work here.
If the file you download doesn't work, please delete it from the #!string!brand_0003!# and then download the file yourself.
Once you have the file, you can upload it to the #!string!brand_0003!# from your computer.
This could take a while if the file is big and if your network is slow.
If this is a USB drive, it may have been unplugged.
This could take over ten minutes, depending on the size of the disc and the speed of your optical drive.
This could take a long time, depending on the speed of the connection between #!string!brand_0020!# and the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This process could take quite some time to complete!
This action can not be undone!
It is possible that another user deleted this file already.
#!string!symbol_0012!# By default, ~256 MiB is set aside for the file system journals.

Once a file transfer starts, it will continue even if you close the page
or the connection times out. If you wish to end the transfer, at this time,
you will need to restart the web server or reboot the dashboard server.
Asking dd to create an image of: [#!variable!device!#] called: [#!variable!name!#] in the: [#!variable!directory!#] directory.

This form is used for creating an #!string!brand_0003!# installation manifest file.
The manifest will be saved locally and can be used later to build new #!string!brand_0003!# system or rebuild/replace a node.

This is a short prefix that describes the owner or department of this #!string!brand_0003!#.
Generally it is two or three characters long and often is an acronym for the company or department.
This is, ultimately, a free-form field to set as you wish. Please only use alphanumeric characters.
This is the company or department domain name. It will be appended to all host names.

This is a sequence number for this #!string!brand_0003!#.
It is combined with the prefix above and, combined, must be unique across your network(s).
Note: Auto-generating IPs only works up to '25'. Beyond that, you need to manually specify the node IPs.
Fill out the rest of the form using default values combined with the "#!string!title_0150!#" answers above.

This is the IP address block and subnet for the #!string!brand_0005!#.
The left field is the network block, ie: 10.20.0.0, and the right field is the subnet mask, ie: 255.255.0.0.

This is the IP address block and subnet for the #!string!brand_0007!#.
The left field is the network block, ie: 10.10.0.0, and the right field is the subnet mask, ie: 255.255.0.0.

This is the IP address block and subnet for the #!string!brand_0009!#.
The left field is the network block, ie: 10.255.0.0, and the right field is the subnet mask, ie: 255.255.0.0.
This is the host name for the first #!string!brand_0003!# node.
This is the host name for the second #!string!brand_0003!# node.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0005!# interface.
This is the network that will be used for cluster communication, management, fencing and live-migration traffic.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0007!# interface.
This is the network that all storage data is replicated over.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0009!# interface.
This is the network all the traffic to and from your servers will travel over.

The IP address of the node's IPMI Interface.
It may be called by other names, like "iRMC", "iLO", "iDRAC", "RSA" or so on, depending on your hardware vendor.
This will be the node's primary fence method.
This is the host name for the first UPS.

The IP address of the first UPS.
If you don't have a UPS, or your UPS does not have a network card, you can leave this blank.
This is the host name for the second UPS.

The IP address of the second UPS.
If you don't have two UPSes, or your UPSes do not have network cards, you can leave this blank.
This is the host name for the first Switched PDU.

The IP address of the first switched PDU.
This is part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.
This is the host name for the second Switched PDU.

The IP address of the second switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.

This is the host name for the first network switch.
If you manage your switches using a serial interface, or if your switches are unmanaged, you can leave this blank.

The IP address of the first network switch.
This isn't very important and can safely be left blank.
It is helpful in that it will add an entry to each node's '/etc/hosts making it easier to connect to it using its host name.

This is the host name for the second network switch.
It may only be useful if you break the switch stack, and can often be safely omitted.

The IP address of the second network switch.
This isn't very important and can safely be left blank, particularly in stacked switch environments.
It is helpful in that it will add an entry to each node's '/etc/hosts making it easier to connect to it using its host name.

This is the host name for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard.
This name, along with the IP addresses below, is used to populate each node's "/etc/hosts" file.
It serves no other purpose and can be left blank if you prefer not to set it.
This is the IP address for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0005!# connection.
This is the IP address for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0009!# connection.

This is the host name for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard, if you have one.
This name, along with the IP addresses below, is used to populate each node's "/etc/hosts" file.
It serves no other purpose and can be left blank if you prefer not to set it.
This is the IP address for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0005!# connection.
This is the IP address for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0009!# connection.

This is the default gateway used to access the Internet on the #!string!brand_0009!# interface.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the primary domain name server used to resolve hostnames to IP address when the given host name was not found in /etc/hosts.
The default IP address of 8.8.8.8 is one of Google's open DNS servers.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the secondary domain name server used to resolve hostnames to IP address when the given host name was not found in /etc/hosts.
The default IP address of 8.8.4.4 is the other of Google's open DNS servers.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the name of this #!string!brand_0003!# in the HA cluster stack's /etc/cluster/cluster.conf file. It must be 15 alphanumeric characters or less.
Generally it will be in the format "<prefix>-#!string!brand_0013!#-<sequence>".

If one of the node's power supplies are plugged into this PDU, enter the outlet number that the power cord is plugged into here.
WARNING: It is very important that this is correct!

This can be used to specify a primary (or sole) internal NTP server if your #!string!brand_0003!# doesn't have access to external time servers.
If you don't have an internal NTP server, leave this blank.
This can be used to specify a backup NTP server, if available.

The "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid IP address or domain name.
Please enter the value as a domain name or IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty.

When an #!string!brand_0003!# node starts, it will boot any servers that it finds powered off
unless is was gracefully shut down by a user. You can use this option to create a boot order
and timing. The left field can be a delay (in seconds) to wait before this server is booted.
If set to '#!string!title_0105!#', the server will not be booted.
The "#!variable!field!#" must be an integer (whole number).
The "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid domain name.

The "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid IP address.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".
Add, edit and remove alert notification targets.
#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty.
#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid domain name.
#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" must be the number of the outlet that the node's PSU is plugged into.

#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid IP address with subnet mask.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address followed by a subnet mask in either dotted-decimal or CIDR format.
The format should be either "a.b.c.d/x" or "a.b.c.d/w.x.y.z".

This will set the password for multiple components of the #!string!brand_0003!#;
Note: To ensure compatibility, the password set for the IPMI user will have spaces and '!' characters removed.
Note: The password will be echoed back to you!
This is needed because the different passwords to set do not share a common encryption form.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty when the IP address is set.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty when the host name is set.

Review the values above. Once you are happy that they are accurate,
press #!string!button_0047!# and the install manifest will be created for you.

This is the amount of space that will be allocated to the "#!string!button_0023!#".
This is where install discs, driver disks and so on are stored for use in servers later.
Generally, the default of 40 GiB is plenty. However, if you only plan to install one type of server, this can be reduced.
On the other hand, if you plan to install many different operating systems on your servers, you may wish to make this larger.

This is the amount of space to allocate to the first storage pool on your #!string!brand_0003!#.
This can be specified as a percentage of the free space, or you can set it to a specific size.
Which ever you choose, the difference will be used to determine the size of the second storage pool automatically.
If you set a static size equal to or larger than the actually available space, or if you choose 100 %, no second storage pool will be created.
The "#!variable!field!#" address block value can not be empty.
The "#!variable!field!#" subnet mask value can not be empty.

The "#!variable!field!#" address block does not appear to be a valid IP address.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".

The "#!variable!field!#" subnet mask does not appear to be a valid IP address.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".
The "#!variable!field!#" value must be between 0 and 100 when the units are % (percentage).
The "#!variable!field!#" must be an integer (whole number) or a floating point (number with a decimal) value.
The "#!variable!field!#" can not be longer than 15 characters.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can only contain alphanumeric characters and dashes (-).
The install manifest has been saved successfully.

Have you reviewed the values that will be set carefully?

If you are happy, enter the current IP address and the current root user's password for both nodes.
This is a new install, so storage will be initialized and any existing data will be lost!

During the install process, the nodes may be rebooted to load a new kernel, if updated, or to reconfigure the network, if needed.

If, for some reason, this #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard can not access the nodes after they reboot, manual intervention will be required.

This installation process might take quite some time to complete, depending on multiple factors like your network speed, machine speed, etc.

Please be patient while the process runs and do not interrupt the process once it has started.

Please be patient!
Some tasks may not cause any output to be displayed for some time.
Please do not reload or leave this page!.

The next step will install required programs on the nodes.
This might take a long time, Please be patient!

The next step will try to update the operating system on the nodes.
This might take a long time, particularly on a slow Internet connection.
Please be patient!
Please review the build plan below and, if you're happy, press "#!string!button_0053!#".
If the storage is OK, but you want to remap the network, press "#!string!button_0054!#".
If the storage is not OK, please edit the install manifest by pressing "#!string!button_0055!#".

In order to access the Red Hat network to download packages, you must register your nodes against Red Hat.
You haven't yet, so you can enter your credentials below and we will register before installing packages.
Please note that this will consume a "Resilient Storage" and the "Optional" repository will be enabled per node.
If registration fails for some reason, the installer will try to proceed anyway.

The install is now beginning. Sanity checks will re-run, just to be safe.
Configuration will begin automatically after that.
Now is a good time to go have a $drink.

The node(s) will now be registered with Red Hat.
This process can take a minute or two, so please be patient.
The "#!variable!field!#" must be a valid URL.

If either node needs to be rebooted, it will be done now.
If both nodes need to be rebooted, they will be rebooted sequentially.
Each node will be given #!conf!sys::reboot_timeout!# seconds to come back online.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty if the field "#!variable!dependent_field!#" is set.
In a two-PDU environment, then both must be defined. In a four PDU environment, at least two must be defined.
#!variable!node!# is set to use an outlet on "#!variable!field!#", but that PDU doesn't have a name and IP set.
#!variable!node!# needs to have outlets set for two PDUs.
This is the host name for the third Switched PDU.

The IP address of the third switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.
This is the host name for the fourth Switched PDU.

The IP address of the fourth switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.

This is the brand name for the first Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.

This is the brand name for the second Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.

This is the brand name for the third Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.

This is the brand name for the fourth Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.
The UPSes will now be told to power cycle.
The UPSes will now be told to power off.

The MTU, or "Maximum Transmission Unit", indicates the largest amount of data that can be sent in a given "packet" of data on a network.
In most cases, leave this as '1500'.
If you are certain all of your network equipment supports a higher MTU though, increasing this may improve performance.
Warning: Do NOT change this unless you know for sure that the larger size will be supported!
The "#!variable!field!#" is too small. The smallest valid MTU size is '576' (see RFC 879).

This controls how a server migrates to the peer node.
If it is "#!string!state_0126!#", the server is migrated while it is running, without service interruption.
In some rare cases, a "#!string!state_0127!#" migration, where the server is gracefully shut down
and then rebooted on the new node, may be preferred.

You can select a script to run before migrating a server.
The text field to the right can be used to pass arguments to your script

You can select a script to run after migrating a server.
The text field to the right can be used to pass arguments to your script

Note: 'Pre' and 'Post' migration scripts are not triggered on a normal boot or recovery.
Scripts can be uploaded in the #!string!button_0023!#.
Create, load or run #!string!brand_0003!# installation manifests.
Disables the ability to build nodes and dashboards.
Enables the ability to network-boot and build nodes and dashboards.
Create a backup of this #!string!brand_0020!# or restore from an old backup.

#!string!brand_0020!# and #!string!brand_0015!# have many configuration options.
Advanced users can tune these in this menu.
There are no existing #!string!brand_0003!# systems yet.
There are no existing owners yet.
Enter the name of the company, group or person who owns this #!string!brand_0003!# system.
There are no existing sending (smtp) mail servers yet.
A short (one line) description which is shown in the #!string!brand_0003!# selection list.

Note: The password here will be displayed back to you.
Note: To change the password, use the '#!data!path::striker-change-password!#' tool.
This is the password used to connect to and control the #!string!brand_0003!#.

The address (name or ip) of node 1.
If you need to use a non-standard port, use 'address:port'.

This is the email server that #!string!brand_0015!# will use to send alerts. If you use a non-standard port,
use 'address:port'. The default port will depend on the connection security being
used. The defaults are 587 for '#!string!select_0003!#', 465 for '#!string!select_0002!#' and 25 for '#!string!select_0001!#.
NOTE: If you plan to use file-based alerts only, blank this field.

This is the name to use when logging into your outgoing mail server.
It is usually, but not always, your email address.

This is the password to use along with the login name above.
Leave it blank if '#!string!row_0303!#' is set to '#!string!select_0004!#'.
This indicates how the password is presented to the server.
This controls the security used when communicating with the outgoing mail server.

Select an existing #!string!brand_0003!# and click on '#!string!button_0048!#' to edit it.
Leave it blank to add a new #!string!brand_0003!#. Click on '#!string!row_0068!#' to remove the selected system.

You can select an existing owner and click '#!string!button_0048!#,
or enter a new one below and it will be added to this list.

You can select an existing outgoing (smtp) mail servers and click '#!string!button_0048!#,
or enter a new one below and it will be added to the list.
A place for you to keep any notes you wish about this owner.
Enter the name of a company, group or person to to use as an #!string!brand_0003!# owner.
A place for you to keep any notes you wish about this SMTP server.
There are no existing notification recipients to send alerts to yet.

You can select an existing notification target to send alerts to,
or enter a new one below and it will be added to the list.

The name of the notification target. If the target is an email address, this is used in the 'To:' field.
If the recipient is a file, this is a short description.

This is the target of the alerts. This can be an email address or a file name.
If it is a file name, the alerts will go to #!data!path::alert_files!# on the machine generating the alert.

This is the language that alerts will be sent using.
Note: At this time, only 'English (Canadian)' is complete.

Debug level is useful for developers trouble-shooting problems with #!string!brand_0015!# or agents.
It will generate an alert on every state change resulting in an extremely high number of alerts.
Information level will generate alerts on state changes that are almost always harmless.

Notice level is the lowest level most regular users will be interested in.
It includes events like server migrations, UPS self-tests and so forth.

Warning level is the level where most technical staff will want to use.
Alerts that may indicate pending issues, like hard drive pre-failure alerts, will use this level.

Critical alerts are what non-technical staff will be interested in.
These are alerts generated by actual component failure, node loss/fence, etc.

Internally, #!string!brand_0015!# uses metric measurements.
If you prefer, you can set this to imperial and values with be converted for the recipient.
All alerts from the #!string!brand_0003!# will be ignored.
A place for you to keep any notes you wish about this alert recipient.
Note: This sets the default alert level and can be overridden for a given #!string!brand_0003!# system.

Below is the raw Install Manifest data. You can customize it as you wish.
Note: Please be careful that you maintain valid XML format.

Optional: A backup email server that #!string!brand_0015!# will use if the main email server stops responding.
A non-standard port can be set the same as above. Note; The backup server
must accept the same credentials and use the same security as the main email server!
One or more UPSes are inaccessible. Power cycle options have been disabled until communication is restored.
If you have a disaster recovery server, you can define it here.
Create DR schedules to cold-image server(s) to a DR target.

You can select an existing disaster recovery target,
or enter a new one below and it will be added to the list.

This is a descriptive name of the disaster recovery target.
You can set this to any name you want.
This is the IP address or resolvable hostname of the target machine.

The TCP port to use for ssh access to the DR target.
The default is 22.

This is the 'root' user's password.
Note: The password will be displayed in plain text!

If selected, DR jobs will check to see if one or more drives with the '#!data!tools::disaster_recovery::cache_signature!#' signature file exists.
Please click on '#!string!button_0003!#' to learn how caching is used.

The type and location where server images will be stored.
Please click on '#!string!button_0003!#' to learn how target stores are used.

How many copies to store of each server.
Note: Be mindful of how much space will be required on the DR target!
You will to have at least (size of all servers * copies). If there is insufficient space, the backup jobs will fail.

This places an upper limit on the bandwidth used when transmitting a server's image over the network to the DR target.
If set to '0', no rate limiting is used and the transfer will occur as quickly as possible.
A place for you to keep any notes you wish about this DR target.
There are no existing disaster recovery targets yet.
There are no existing disaster recovery jobs yet.

You can select an existing disaster recovery job,
or enter a new one below and it will be created.

There are no existing #!string!brand_0003!# systems yet.
You will not be able to save a DR job until one exists.

Select an existing #!string!brand_0003!# system and click '#!string!button_0048!#,
to update the list of servers available to select for this job.
There are no servers to select for this job yet.

Defining locations allows hosts to be grouped by physical location,
which improves the intelligence of the decision engine in emergency
and recovery conditions.
The host name (or IP address) of the #!string!brand_0015!# database server.

The host name (or IP address) of the #!string!brand_0015!# database server
Note: Clearing this field will delete the existing DB
The TCP port that the #!string!brand_0015!# database is listening on.
The user name to use when connecting to the #!string!brand_0015!# database.

The database user's password.
Note: Changing this will NOT change the current database password!

It looks like we are about to rebuild or replace a node.
Please be sure to check that the passwords set in the manifest match the ones currently in use!

A server was found to be running on a node while the 'cman' daemon was stopped.
This should never happen.

The download has been queued and will start shortly.
In a moment, the download progress page will load.
You can safely go back to the main page if you wish.
The URL: [#!variable!url!#] is in queue for download
Any pending or active downloads will be shown below.
Use Lanplus (needed on most HP nodes).
Used to set default IPs and hostnames.
The first node's hostname will be changed to this value.
The second node's hostname will be changed to this value.
Sets the IP on the bcn_bond1 interface.
Sets the IP on the sn_bond1 interface.
Sets the IP on the ifn_bridge1 interface.
Sets the IP of the IPMI BMC. Used for the primary fence method.
Used to populate /etc/hosts. UPSes are monitored by #!string!brand_0015!#.
Used to populate /etc/hosts. PDUs are used for backup fence actions.
If this node plugs into this PDU, enter the outlet number.
Sets the OS, cluster and IPMI passwords.
Size (static or relative) of storage for node 1's servers. Balance, if any, allocated to node 2.
Select an existing item to use it again for this #!string!brand_0003!#
These fields tell the system where to find, how to access what to do with alerts
These fields tell #!string!brand_0015!# how to send email alerts. This section is very similar to setting up an email client's 'sending' mail server.
These #!string!brand_0003!# systems are currently owned by this owner.
These #!string!brand_0003!# systems currently using this SMTP server to send alerts.
Select an existing item to use it again for this #!string!brand_0015!#

This shows the usage of resources by servers, and resources remaining free. It outputs in XML format or, with '--pretty', in a human-readable format.
SWITCHES
--pretty
Print the output in a human-readable format.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialogue and exit.

The kernel module: [#!variable!module!#] is already loaded on both nodes. -=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!# DESCRIPTION This program checks to see if it can talk to the peer node on boot. If it can, it performs a series of sanity checks to make sure everything is healthy. If all is well, the nodes will start the cluster stack and then servers will be booted. Servers that were gracefully shut down, and servers set to never boot, will be skipped. SWITCHES --abort This will cause any running instances of this program to be killed. --disable Prevent this tool from starting on boot. Be sure to disable it on BOTH nodes! --enable Enable this tool on boot. Note that if this is enable on either node, the #!string!brand_0004!# will be started. --force Normally, if another instance of this program is already running, this instance will immediately exit. Using this switch skips this check and forces the instance to run. Be careful using this! --state, --status Reports whether this tool is enabled on boot or not. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. If so, you will need to recover the server before trying to shut down again. -=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!# DESCRIPTION This program shuts down an #!string!brand_0004!# node. Which node shuts down depends on how it is invoked. If it is invoked with '--local', the local machine will be shut down *unless* it is the SyncSource for the peer (it has data on the replicated storage the peer doesn't). In such a case, the program will throw an error and exit with a non-0 exit code. If it is invoked with '--shed-load', then which node shuts down depends on several criteria in a certain priority order. 1. Can the peer be reached? If not, load shedding is aborted (as it is assumed the peer is already offline, in this context). 2. If one node is the 'SyncSource' for the other, then the Inconsistent peer will be shut down. NOTE: if *both* nodes are SyncSource (on different storage pools), the load shed will throw an error and exit with a non-0 exit code. 3. If both nodes are UpToDate, and one node's health is not 'OK', then the sick node will be shut down. 4. If both nodes are UpToDate and healthy, the the sum of the RAM used by servers on each node is added. The node with the least amount of RAM used by servers will shutdown. 5. If the RAM in use by servers on both nodes is the same, node 2 will shut down. In all cases, the node that is shutting down will try to migrate its servers to the peer. The only exception will be when the peer is also in a 'warning' or 'critical' state (which indicates an external issue, like low UPS batteries or an over-temperature event). In such a case, the server that is shutting down will gracefully shut down servers running on it. SWITCHES --cold-stop This is basically '--shed-load --reason cold_stop'. It adjusts the output reported to the user but then uses the same logic as load shedding. Striker uses this during a "Cold Stop" operation to reuse the same logic to determine which node to shut down first. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --local Shut this machine down. --reason X If set, the string passed in will be set in the stop reason column for servers that are shut down. The reason can not contain spaces or non-alpha-numeric characters. The default stop reason is 'clean', or 'shed-load' if '--shed-load' was used. --shed-load Picks a node to turn off based on the above criteria. --suicide When set, 'anvil-node-suicide' is called as a backgroud progress before starting the withdraw. That will cause this machine to commit suicide via self-fence if the machine hasn't withdrawn from the cluster in 300 seconds (or as set via 'anvil-node-suicide --delay X'. NOTE: The timer starts AFTER the last server has shut down. --withdraw-only Performs the safe-stop logic, but exits when the node is withdrawn from the system instead of shutting down. If 'virt-manager' is installed and if 'tools::striker-configure-vmm::enabled = 1', the nodes for the deleted #!string!brand_0004!# will be removed from any system user's virtual machine manager the next time they log into the desktop. NOTE This does NOT delete the #!string!brand_0004!# from the peer dashboard! This will need to be called on each dashboard before they are sync'ed or else the deleted #!string!brand_0004!# will come back. SWITCHES --anvil This is the name of the #!string!brand_0004!# to delete. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# Backing up: [#!variable!source!#] to: [#!variable!destination!#]. #!variable!this_file!# has started. Deleting the #!string!brand_0004!# named: [#!variable!anvil!#] with ID: [#!variable!anvil_id!#]. Must be called with '--anvil '. The #!string!brand_0004!# called: [#!variable!anvil!#] was not found in: [#!data!path::striker_config!#] -=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!# DESCRIPTION This takes a command and runs it sometime in the future, redirecting output from the call to a temporary file. This is done using a random token given to the initial caller and then adding itself to crontab. When called again with that token via crontab, it deletes itself from cron and then executes the requested command, writing out any output to: '/tmp/token..txt'. NOTE When called without a token, the generated token out command output file will be printed; token: [] output: [] Note that the output should match above, but the parser should handle an arbitrary number of spaces between ':' and '['. The 'output' file will terminate with a single line containing 'sdr-rc:X' where 'X' is the called program's return code. SWITCHES --call '/path/to/call [args]' This is the command to call. If your command uses single-quotes in the argument list, escape them. --delay This is the number of second to delay. Note that it gets rounded up to the next even minute, which is crontab's resolution. For example, if this is set to '30' and the time in 10:22:45, the delay will set to 10:23:15, then rounded up to 10:24:00. The primary goal is to ensure that if a command needs to be coordinated between machines, assuming the machines are in time sync, they will all run at the same time. So the delay acts as a buffer of sorts in case the caller is requesting a delay very close to the start of the next minute (ie: it sets the delay at 10:22:59 on one machine and 10:23:01 on another, they would trigger one minute apart with no delay). If you don't care about coordinating actions, you can ignore this and the call will happen within one minute. --token This is the token used for the run. Normally the caller will never set this as it is generated automatically and used in the crontab file. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# Crontab line: [#!variable!line!#] has our token: [#!variable!token!#], removing it. Rewrote the crontab file to remove our entry. Added the entry: [#!variable!crontab_string!#] to crontab. Called with token: [#!variable!token!#], beginning run of delayed call. Must be called with '--call ""'. The requested call: [#!variable!call!#] seems to match the existing entry: [#!variable!line!#]. This is usually caused by a bug in a program calling is too many times. #!variable!this_file!# has started. The run is finished. Writing out the new jobs file: [#!data!path::anvil-jobs!#] with still-queued job(s). No queued jobs left, removing the jobs file: [#!data!path::anvil-jobs!#]. Writing out the new jobs file: [#!data!path::anvil-jobs!#] with the aborted job(s) removed. There was a malformed line in the queue: [#!variable!line!#]. It has been removed. -=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!# DESCRIPTION This program is designed to run once per minute from cron. When it runs, it looks to see if #!data!path::anvil-jobs!# exists. If it doesn't, the program exits. If it does, it is read in and parsed. The format is: ::'' The 'time' field is a unix time stamp. If the current time is equal to or greater than the time stamp, the command is run. If not, it is left in the queue for later. The token is used to track the job and is used to generate the file where the call's STDOUT is written. Once a job is started, it is removed from the queue. If no jobs are left, the jobs file is removed. NOTE Jobs are queued by AN::Tools::System->synchronous_command_run(). This is not meant to be used by other tools or applications, though there should be no harm in doing so. SWITCHES --abort This will remove the queued job with the matching string (usually the token, but the command could be used as well). Note that if the job has already started, it will NOT be cancelled. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# #!variable!this_file!# has started. Not running as 'root', unable to control system daemons. Asked to set a daemon: [#variable!daemon!#] to: [#!variable!state!#]. Either the daemon is not recognized or the state is not allowed. Failed to start: [#!variable!daemon!#], rolling back. Failed to stop: [#!variable!daemon!#], rolling back. -=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!# DESCRIPTION This program enables and disables the 'Install Target' feature. It does this primarily by turning dhcpd on and off, and adjusting the firewall as needed. SWITCHES --disable Disable the install target feature. If it is already disabled, it does nothing and exits with a success. --enable Enable the install target feature. If it is already enabled, it does nothing and exits with a success. --state, --status Shows whether the install target feature is currently enabled or not. Note: Regardless of the language used, the state/status will always print 'state:X' which callers can parse. 0 = Stopped 1 = Running 2 = Unknown state (error) Note: If the program hits an error, it will exit with 'rc:X'. Consult the program header to determine what error codes mean. A message relating to the fault will be logged and printed to STDOUT. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# Install target is currently enabled. Install target is currently disabled. Install target is currently unknown. Install target is now enabled. Install target is now disabled. Successfully started: [#!variable!daemon!#]. Successfully stopped: [#!variable!daemon!#]. #!variable!this_file!# has started. It can also report on the progress of downloads happening in the background. Lastly, it can abort currently running downloads. When called with no arguments, it reports the status of other downloads, if any. SWITCHES --abort <{uuid,pid}> Abort the download underway given either the UUID of the download or the process ID of the instance performing the download. --delete When used with '--delete', the associated download file is deleted. --script This will cause the downloaded file to be set executable (chmod a+x). --url <{ftp,http,https}://example.com/path/to/file> Attempt to download the file at the given URL. -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# #!variable!this_file!# has started. -=] Server Summary DESCRIPTION This program loops through all configured Anvil! system and reports on the servers hosted on that Anvil! system. Optionally, a single Anvil! name can be passed if you want to see the current servers that specific system. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --anvil This option allows you to specify the Anvil! you want to query. This can either be the Anvil! name or its UUID. EXAMPLE Get a list of all servers on all configured Anvil! systems. ./anvil-server-summary Restrict the list of servers to the 'an-anvil-05' Anvil!. ./anvil-server-summary --anvil an-anvil-05 SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# -=] Find Drives DESCRIPTION This program returns a list of local block devices on the system. Optical drives, tape drives and other non-standard block devices are ignored. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --signature When set, only drives with a file in the root of the disk with this string as its name will be reported. --no-mount By default, if a block device is found and not mounted, it will be mounted momentarily so that a check can be made to see if the drive has a signature file as well as to report on the size of the disk and the amount of free space (when the disk has a supported file system on it). This switch prevents this behaviour causing unmounted disks to be ignored. EXAMPLE Get a list of all servers on all configured Anvil! systems. ./anvil-server-summary Restrict the list of servers to the 'an-anvil-05' Anvil!. ./anvil-server-summary --anvil an-anvil-05 SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# -=] Anvil! Report State DESCRIPTION This program gathers up state information about the system and reports what it finds as 'variable = value' pairs. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. -f, --fast This skips rescanning LVM and does not load server XML data. This increases the run speed by about 25%. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# -=] Anvil! CLI State DESCRIPTION This program reports basic status information in a user-friendly way formatted for the command line. NOTE This is designed for a terminal that is at least 110 columns wide. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. -i, --interval X This tells the program to run until killed (ctrl + c). The 'X' must be an integer and will set how frequently the program loops. NOTE: It takes about 1 second to gather the details and prepare the data for display. So a value of '1' here will mean the delay is actually about 2 seconds. NOTE: Using an interval of less than 10 is not recommended for extended periods of time as it will place a high load on some nodes. When an interval less than 10 is used, a warning will be displayed to remind the user to not leave the monitor running longer than necessary. Exiting. -=] Striker Change Password DESCRIPTION This program is used to change the password of the local striker dashboard or an Anvil! node pair. When changing the local Striker dashboard password, it will attempt to log into any Anvil! nodes it knows about and update their password for this dashboard's ScanCore database. However, if any node is unavailable, you will need to manually update the password later. NOTE: 1. This tool only runs on Striker dashboards. 2. This tool must be run as the 'root' user. 3. This tool does NOT require the old password. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --anvil This is used to change the password on an Anvil! node pair. It will change the root and ricci user passwords on both nodes. --ipmi-user When using a local dashboard that has IPMI (iRMC, iLO, DRAC, etc), you can use this switch to indicate which IPMI user's password to updated. Without this switch, IPMI on a Striker dashboard will NOT be changed. --force When changing the local Striker dashboard password, the program will log into all nodes and our peer dashboard(s) that we know of. If any are not accessible, the program will abort. This switch force the password change to happen even when nodes are offline. This means you will have to update the inaccessible nodes' striker.conf file manually. This switch will also override minimum password length requirements. This switch will NOT override changing an Anvil! password with a node being offline. --local This is used to change the local dashboard's password. It will change the root user's password, the Striker web interface password and the ScanCore database password. --password This is the new password that will be set. NOTE: You must be aware of standard shell escaping! See: http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/escapingsection.html -y, --yes Don't prompt for confirmation before proceeding. The 'anvil-test-pre-migration' script was called for the server: [#!variable!server!#] which appears to not be running. -=] Striker Update DESCRIPTION This is a test script used during Striker release testing use to verify the post-migration script functionality. It takes '--server ' and logs it to the main Striker log file, and nothing more. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --server The name of the server that was just migrated. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# The server: [#!variable!server!#] is currently on: [#!variable!host!#] and was migrated from: [#!variable!peer!#]. The 'anvil-test-post-migration' script was invoked without '--server '. The 'anvil-test-post-migration' script was called for the server: [#!variable!server!#] which does not appear to exist in this #!string!brand_0004!#. The 'anvil-test-post-migration' script was called for the server: [#!variable!server!#] which appears to not be running. -=] Anvil! Manage Disks DESCRIPTION This program is designed to make it easy to manage physical disks in a server. It can add, remove or grow the logical volumes that back the virtual disks in a server. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --lv This is the full path of the source device (logical volume) being added, removed or grown. --size This is the size of a new disk to add, or the amount of space to add to an existing disk. This switch is only useful with the 'add' and 'grow' tasks. Note that the size will be in GiB. If you want to specify a different size unit, add the suffix to the digit without a space. For example, '--size 500M' or '--size 500MiB' will be '500 MiB', or you can force a base-10 size with '--size 500MB' will be 500 MB. --server This is the name of the server to work on. --task This is the task to perform. Valid tasks are; * add: Add a disk (logical volume) to the server. If the LV already exists, it will be added as-is. If no source is given, a new disk of the requested '--size' will be created and added. * grow: This will grow the '--lv' LV to add the requested '--size'. * remove: This will remove the '--lv' LV from the server. * show: This will list the currently attached LVs and their sizes for the given server, as well as any volume groups available and their size / free space. --vg If two or more volume groups exist, and you want to add a new disk that does not yet exist, this switch tells the program what VG to use when it creates the disk. This is required in such cases. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# - Name: [#!variable!vg!#], Size: [#!variable!say_size!# (#!variable!size!# Bytes)], Free space: [#!variable!say_free!# (#!variable!free!# Bytes)]. I am about to add a new disk to: [#!variable!server!#] on volume group: [#!variable!vg!#] of the size: [#!variable!say_size!#], which will leave: [#!variable!say_free!#] space left for future use. - Proceed? [y/N] The '-y' switch was used, proceeding automatically. Thank you, proceeding now. Aborting. Creating: [#!variable!lv_path!#] now... - Success! Temporarily defining the server. The new drive will be attached to the target: [#!variable!target!#]. Created the backup of the definition file: [#!variable!backup!#]. Updating the server's definition file: [#!variable!definition_file!#]. Removing the temporariry definition. Done! Existing volume groups: logical volumes (disks) under the server: [#!variable!server!#]: - Device: [#!variable!lv!#], Target device: [#!variable!target!#], Size: [#!variable!say_size!# (#!variable!size!# Bytes)]. Detaching: [#!variable!lv!#] from: [#!variable!server!#]. Detached successfully. I am about to remove the disk (LV): [#!variable!lv!#] from the [#!variable!server!#]. This LV is: [#!variable!say_size!# (#!variable!size!# Bytes)] big. NOTE: This LV will *NOT* be deleted. If you want to remove it permanently, after it is detached successfully, run: lvremove #!variable!lv!# - Proceed? [y/N] I am about to attach the existing disk (LV): [#!variable!lv!#] to the [#!variable!server!#]. This LV is: [#!variable!say_size!# (#!variable!size!# Bytes)] big. - Proceed? [y/N] I am about to modify the server: [#!variable!server!#] by growing the logical volume: [#!variable!lv!#]. I will add: [#!variable!requested!#], growing it from from: [#!variable!lv_size!#] to: [#!variable!new_lv_size!#]. This is on the volume group: [#!variable!vg!#], which will have: [#!variable!left_over!#] free when done. NOTE: Depending on your operating system, you may not see the new space immediately. Consult your operating system documentation on how to see new disk space added to a system. On many older OSes, a reboot will be necessary. If the grown disk stores the OS's file, additional steps may be needed to grow the file system. - Proceed? [y/N] Extending: [#!variable!lv_path!#] now... The new space has been added successfully! No server name was passed. Please specify with '--server '. No '--task' specified. See '-h' for usage information. This tool must be run on an Anvil! node. The server is not running on this node. Please run this tool on the current host: [#!variable!host!#]. Unable to add a disk when neither '--vg X' or '--size X' are specified. The available VGs are Unable to add a disk because '--vg X' wasn't specified and there are: [#!variable!count!#] VGs. The available VGs are: The requested volume group: [#!variable!vg!#] doesn't appear to exist. The available VGs are: The requested size is more than is available. You difference was: [#!variable!say_left_over!# (#!variable!say_left_over!# bytes)]. The available VGs are: There was a problem trying to find a free logical volume name for the new LV. Please contact support or run again with '-vvv' and then check the /var/log/striker.log file for possible clues as to what went wrong. - Failed! It would appear the attempt to create the new disk failed for some reason. Please contact support or run again with '-vvv' and then check the /var/log/striker.log file for possible clues as to what went wrong We were unable to find a target device (vdX). This can happen if the server has 26 drives already. The new drive failed to attach to the server. The error was: ==== #!variable!error!# ==== No logical volume specified to remove. The requested LV: [#!variable!lv!#] does not appear to be attached to this server. Try '--show' to see a list of connected drives. The drive failed to detach to the server. The error was: ==== #!variable!error!# ==== No logical volume specified to grow. No size given to add the the logical volume. The requested size: [#!variables!size!#] appears to be invalid. Unable to convert it to a byte size. The drive failed to detach to the server. The error was: ==== #!variable!error!# ==== -=] Anvil! Manage Disks DESCRIPTION This program moves a server from one Anvil! node pair to another. For this program to work, certain conditions MUST be met. 1. Passwordless ssh must be setup between the root user on this host and the root user on the target node. 2. The target node must be a member of a clustet (the peer can be off, but cman and rgmananger must be running on the target). 3. The server must not be running. 4. There must be enough space (disk and RAM) for the server. 5. The local machine must be in the cluster (the peer doesn't have to be). With these conditions being met, the migration is performed thusly; 1. If the server's XML definition file doesn't exist already, a check is made to ensure there is enough RAM available for the server on the local cluster. 2. LVs matching the source LVs are created (unless they already exist). 3. The dd commands are prepared and shown. Each LV can be imaged or skipped. 3.1 For LVs that are imaged; an 'md5sum' is calculated after the migration of both the source and target LVs, unless '--no-sums' is used. 4. The definition file is copied over, being modified as needed. 5. If both nodes are running in the local cluster, the server is added to the local Anvil! system. SWITCHES -h, -?, --help Show this dialogue and exit. --new-name Optional; If you want to change the name of the server on the local cluster, this switch lets you do it. --server This is the name of the server to be rehomed. It must match the name of the server on that target. --target This is the host name or IP address of the remote node we will be pulling the server from. Passwordless SSH must be setup between this machine and root@. SUPPORT #!string!brand_0012!# #!string!brand_0001!# The server: [#!data!switches::server!#] was found on the target and it is off. Gathering migration data now. - RAM: ..... [#!variable!ram!#] - CPU Cores: [#!variable!cpu!#] - Disks: ... [#!variable!disks!#] - Disk: ... [#!variable!lv!#], size: [#!variable!size!#], block size: [#!variable!block!#] May I create the new logical volume: [#!variable!lv!#]? [Y/n] - Auto-yes, proceeding. Aborting. If you create an LV with the same name manually (on any VG), it will be used. - Created successfully! - The target LV: [#!variable!lv!#] already exists, no need to create it. Preparing storage; Storage is ready! [ NOTE ] - The network bridge has changed from: [#!variable!old_bridge!#] to: [#!variable!new_bridge!#]. The new XML definition file has been saved as: [#!variable!file!#]. The logical volume: [#!variable!lv!#] (#!variable!size!#) doesn't exist. Trying to create it now. ============================================================================== The copy of: [#!variable!from_lv!#] (#!variable!size!#) from: [#!variable!target!#] to the local: [#!variable!to_lv!#] logical volume will begin in: [#!variable!delay!#] seconds. Press + now to abort. If the copy runs at about 100 MiB/sec (typical for gigabit), the copy should take about: [#!variable!finished!#] (#!variable!seconds!# seconds). The progress will be displayed below every few seconds. ============================================================================== - Percent complete: [#!variable!percent!#%], Time left: [#!variable!remaining!#], MiB/sec: [#!variable!speed!#], Copied: [#!variable!copied!# / #!variable!size!#]. Done! This appears to be a node, so the next step would be to define the server. To do this, run; # virsh define #!variables!definition!# Done! This appears to be a node, so please go to Striker and you should see that the server has been found and is ready to add to your Anvil! system! NOTE! Remember to remove the server from the target once you are certain the migration was successful! If you wish to calculate md5sums, run the following commands. Open two terminals and you can run the target and local commands in parallel. No target node was passed. Please specify with '--target '. No server name was passed. Please specify with '--server '. The server: [#!data!switches::server!#] wasn't found on the target. Perhaps there was a problem talking to the target (is passwordless SSH setup?). Is the server name correct (it is case sensitive)? Output (if any) is below; ==== #!variable!output!# ==== The server: [#!data!switches::server!#] is: [#!variable!state!#]. It must be stopped (or disabled) before we can proceed. Failed to read (or parse) ther server's definition file: [#!variables!file!#]. Output (error of what was read) is below; ==== #!variable!output!# ==== Failed to find the physical extent size for the volume group: [#!variable!vg!#]. Failed to find a VG suitable to use for the old LV: [#!variable!lv!#]. - Failed! The attempt to create the LV failed. Here is the output; ==== #!variable!output!# ==== Use '--help' for usage information.
